Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Model diagnostics in regression and Tobit regression models with measurement error
Award.AbstractNarration:
Statistical modeling for relationships between a collection of predictors and a response is often implemented by regression analysis. In the classical regression model, both predictors and response variables are assumed to be directly observable. In measurement error regression models, predictors cannot be observed directly, instead, some surrogates are observed. In Tobit regression models, the response variable is observed only when it is above some threshold. The development of useful and optimal inference procedures in the presence of measurement errors in regression and Tobit regression models is of major concern in theoretical and applied statistics. Despite this need, the study of goodness-of-fit and lack-of-fit tests in the measurement error regression models and Tobit regression models with/without measurement errors has lagged behind. In this project, the investigators analyze goodness-of-fit tests for the distributions of the random components of errors-in-variables and Berkson measurement error regression models, and some nonparametric estimators of regression functions in Tobit regression models with or without these measurement errors. Furthermore, the investigators develop and analyze lack-of-fit and goodness-of-fit tests in Tobit regression models with these measurement errors. The investigators make available some new, useful, and optimal inference procedures in these models with an in-depth understanding of their theoretical properties to a wide professional audience in statistics and related disciplines. This project is at the cutting edge of model checking in the presence of measurement error in predictors in regression and Tobit regression models. It advances and enriches the statistical theory and methodology, thereby helping to fill a significant void and well recognized theoretical gap that exists in statistics.

Measurement errors are very prevalent in the health sciences, physical sciences, economics, and the social sciences. For example, when investigating the effect of diet on breast cancer, one of the predictor variables studied for predicting breast cancer is the long-term saturated fat intake which cannot be measured precisely. Instead, the surrogate of a 24 hour diet recall for each patient is often used in this type of investigation. Similarly, the exact amount of radiation a person is exposed to when studying the effect of radiation exposure on humans is often measured with error. In labor studies, when investigating the relationship between women's working status and their background information, such as age, education and working experience, the effect of measurement errors is present in the education variables (such as mother's and father's education experience). Tobit regression models, which are used in these types of studies, often suffer from the measurement error problem. Most empirical studies involving Tobit regression models tend to ignore the measurement errors, which usually leads to biased and inefficient statistical conclusions. The research focus of this project, which helps in assessing the accuracy of a regression model or of a model for the distributions of random components in the presence of measurement errors, helps to develop more accurate statistical inference for these and other similar examples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this proposal were to develop and analyze goodness-of-fit tests for the distributions of the random components of errors-in-variables and Berkson measurement error regression models, and some nonparametric estimators of regression functions in Tobit regression models with or without these measurement errors. Furthermore, it was proposed to develop and analyze lack-of-fit and goodness-of-fit tests in Tobit measurement error regression models.

The outcomes of the project were as follows.

The three students Abhishek KAUL, Xiaoqing ZHU and Pei GENG were in part supported by this grant. Abhishek was supported during the AY 2013-2014 and Xiaoqing from August 16, 2014 till June 30, 2015, and Pei Geng from 8/16/2015 to 12/15/2015.  The first two graduated by the end of Summer 2015 and the third plans to graduate in SS2016.  Their thesis produced useful and important tests for  model diagnostics for big data, regression models with measurement error and Tobit regression models. In all the following papers were produced during the tenure of this grant.

1.  Kaul, Abhishek. (2014). Lasso with Long Memory Regression Errors. J. Statist. Planning and Inference, vol. 153, 11--26.

2. Kaul, Abhishek and  Koul, H.L. (2015). Weighted $\ell_1$-Penalized Corrected Quantile Regression for High Dimensional Measurement Error Models.  J. Mult.  Analysis, vol. 140, 72--91.

3. Koul, H.L. and Zhu, Xiaoqing. (2015).  Goodness-of-fit Testing of Error Distribution in Nonparametric ARCH(1) Models.  J. Mult. Analysis,
vol. 137, 141--160.

4. Xiaoqing Zhu, Weixing Song and Hira L. Koul. (2015). Goodness-of-fit Testing of Error Distribution in Linear Measurement Error Models. Submitted.

5. Koul, Hira L. and Song, Weixing. (2014).  Simulation extrapolation estimation in parametric models with Laplace measurement error.  Electron. J. Stat., vol. 8, pp 1973--1995.

6. Koul, Hira L. and Song, Weixing. (2016). Minimum distance partial linear regression model checking with Berkson measurement errors.  J. Statist. Planning & Inference,  vol. 174,  129--152.

7. Jureckova, J., Koul, H.L., Navratil, R., and Picek, J. (2016).   Behavior of R-estimators under measurement errors.  Bernoulli, vol. 22,  1093--1112.

8.  Kaul, A., Koul, H.L., Chawla, A. \& Lahiri, S. (2016). Two stage non-penalized corrected least squares for high dimensional linear models with measurement error or missing covariates. Submitted.

9. Koul, Hira L., Song, Weixing and Shan Liu. (2014). Model checking in tobit regression via nonparametric smoothing.  J. Multi. Analysis, vol.125, 36--49.

10. Geng, Pei. (2016). Parameter estimation for the logistic regression model under case-control study. Statist. Probab. Lett., vol. 109, 168--177.

11. Koul, H.L., Xie, C. and Zhu, L. (2016). An adaptive-to-model test for parametric single-index errors-in-variables models.  Submitted.

12. Geng, Pei and Koul, H.L.  (2016). Model checking in Tobit regression with measurement errors using validation data. Submitted.

13. Koul, Hira L. and Song, Weixing. (2013). Large sample results for varying kernel regression estimates.  J. Nonparameric Statist., vol. 25, 829--853.

14. Koul, H.L., Muller, U. and Schick, A. (2016) Estimating the error distribution in a single-index model. Submitted.

15. Koul, H.L. and Surgailis, D. (2013).  Goodness-of-fit tests for marginal distribution of linear random fields with long memory. MSU RM\#702

16. Koul, Hira L, Mimoto, N. and Sugailis, D. (2016). A Goodness-of-fit test for marginal distribution of linear random fields with long memory.  Metrika, vol. 79, 165--193.

17. Koul, H.L., Surgailis, D. and N. Mimoto. (2015). Minimum distance lack-of-fit tests under long memory errors. Metrika, vol. 78, 119--143.

18. Koul, H.L. and Wang, Lihong. (2016). Smooth estimation of error distribution in nonparametric regression under long memory. Submitted.

19. Dalla, V., Giraitis, L., and  Koul, H.L. (2014). Studentizing weighted sums of linear processes. J. Time Series Analysis, vol. 35,  151--172.

20. Indeewara Perera and Koul, H.L. (2016). Fitting a two phase threshold multiplicative error model. Submitted.

 

In all of these papers a variety of testing procedures are developed for either fitting a regression function or an error distribution function or error density funtion in regression models with measurement error in covariates. In each case some finite and large sample properties of the proposed tests are reported. All tests are asymptotically distribution free. Some paper deal with fitting marginal distributions to long memory time series and random fields. All tests are applicable in a variety of fields including econometrics, geology, hydrology, environmental sciences and health sciences.

By training three students the project enhanced an important human rsource. It also extended the domain of applications of modern statistical methodology to  new frontiers.
